newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX crude breaks support in last hour of trade.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX crude breaks support in last hour of trade.

text.p: NYMEX crude oil prices broke key near-term support of $21.80 a barrel in the afternoon but traders didn't see much downside potential as a technical consolidation in heating oil lent crude support.
"It's broken that support but doesn't seem very anxious, so it might rebound," said one trader.
However, traders noted some sell stops around the $21.75 level were triggered, with the support seen at around $21.45. Resistance was pegged at $22.05 a barrel.
October crude stood 38 cents lower at $21.73 a barrel, as the October-November spread coming in to 50 cents.
They also cited a bearish build up in crude stocks indicated by weekly data by the American Petroleum Institute.
The October heating-to-crude crack was had widened $0.20 to $4.00 a barrel, traders said, with the strength in heat limiting crude's losses.
"Heat is preventing crude from plummeting," said one trader.
September heating oil was 0.62 cent lower at 61.05 cents a gallon, while September gasoline, posting the sharpest losses, was 1.11 cents lower at 62.90 cents a gallon.
"Gasoline is just really putrid right now," a trader said.
Traders were hammering down the September gasoline contract after weekly data from the U.S Energy Information Administration showed an unexpected build in gasoline stocks.
-- Harry Milling, New York Energy Desk +1 212 859 1620
